FitCult  |  School Project

May 2023

Web application built by a team of 5 developers following weekly Agile sprints.
Role: full‑stack developer & scrum facilitator.

FitCult lets users create an account, store body‑metrics (weight, height, lean mass), set fitness goals (weight loss, lean, bulk, etc.) and upload progress photos. All data is persisted in Firebase NoSQL. Front‑end built with HTML + JavaScript; screenshots show landing, registration/payment, goal‑tracking dashboard and team credits.

HTML 5 JavaScript CSS Firebase NoSQL Agile/Scrum

Once the application is executed the analyst will see the screen below. On the screen, the analyst will have two options:
Analyst can type a project name and select a rollup to create a new project
Analyst can select a saved project and type initials to resume a previous project

Dashboard to display Network Map, TAK Map, Pivot Map and network statistics.
At the left-hand side, analyst can access the two different dashboards.
CyberVA Dashboard will display all Nodes that are available from the INVA/DE rollup.
To access click on the blue View button.

Dashboard to display network vulnerability and Environmental information.
If there are any errors during the selection of the use case, the system shall show an error on a pop-up window and end the process.
To access click on the blue View button.

NAÏVE  |  School Project

May 2023

NAÏVE (Network Assessment, INVA/DE Viewer E-Tool) is a web application built to run on Kali Linux systems both locally and on the cloud (AWS/Azure).
Role: full‑stack developer & database designer.

Designed to help cybersecurity analysts aggregate and visualize data gathered during network assessments. NAÏVE integrates modern penetration testing tools, pipes data into backend database tables, and presents mission-critical insights through intuitive dashboards.

Kali Linux Python Web Development Penetration Testing Cloud Deployment Cybersecurity

Multiple‑Sequence Alignment Script   |  Undergrad Research

Sep 2022

Independent research under Dr. Daniel DeBlasio focused on improving multiple‑sequence alignment (MSA) accuracy by integrating secondary‑structure data.

Wrote a Python script that preprocesses FASTA files, augments alignments with DSSP‑derived constraints, and outputs refined MSA ready for downstream analysis. Executed large‑scale runs on a Linux server via command line.

Python Linux CLI Bioinformatics
Read Published Paper
